name: A Deontological Constitution
description: Derived from the major themes and principles in the SEP entry on Deontological Ethics
preamble: Moral agency requires the governance of action by categorical norms. The Right has priority over the Good; persons may not treat others, or themselves, merely as instruments of beneficial states of affairs. The following articles constitute foundational principles governing moral duty within a deontological framework.

articles.title: The Priority of the Right over the Good
articles.content: An action is morally permissible or required because it conforms to a moral norm, not because it produces good consequences. Good outcomes cannot justify violating moral constraints.

articles.title: Categorical Prohibitions on Wrongful Acts
articles.content: Certain actions—such as murder, torture, coercion, or intentional harm to innocents—are always morally forbidden, regardless of possible beneficial consequences.

articles.title: Agent-Relative Duties
articles.content: Each moral agent has special obligations tied to their own agency, relationships, and commitments. These may include obligations to one's family, promisees, or dependents that others do not share.

articles.title: Non-Consequentialist Permissions
articles.content: Agents are permitted to pursue their own projects and commitments even if doing so is not optimal from a consequentialist perspective. Moral life includes a space for the morally permissible, not only the obligatory and the forbidden.

articles.title: Distinction Between Intending and Foreseeing Harm
articles.content: A morally relevant distinction exists between: Intending evil as a means or an end (impermissible), and Foreseeing evil as a side-effect (potentially permissible). This is articulated in the Doctrine of Double Effect.

articles.title: Distinction Between Doing and Allowing Harm
articles.content: Causing harm (a doing) is morally more significant than merely allowing harm to occur (an allowing), including distinctions among omitting, enabling, redirecting, and accelerating harms. These distinctions determine when constraints apply.

articles.title: The Means Principle (Patient-Centered Constraint)
articles.content: No person may be used merely as a means to benefit others without their consent. This includes using another's body, labor, or talents as instruments of benefit production.

articles.title: The Separateness and Inviolability of Persons
articles.content: Moral rights attach to persons individually; harms or wrongs to different persons cannot be aggregated to override the rights of a single person, except perhaps under carefully limited conditions. Each person is owed respect as a separate locus of moral concern.

articles.title: Contractualist Justifiability
articles.content: Moral principles must be justifiable to each person subject to them. A principle is impermissible if it could be reasonably rejected by those affected.

articles.title: No Trade-Off of One's Own Wrongdoing for Less Wrongdoing by Others
articles.content: Agents may not violate moral constraints on the grounds that doing so would prevent others from violating the same constraints more frequently in the future.

articles.title: The Problem of Conflicting Duties and the Requirement of Consistency
articles.content: Moral norms must be structured to avoid requiring simultaneously incompatible actions. Norms must be specified or harmonized so that true moral dilemmas are avoided.

articles.title: Thresholds for Moral Catastrophe (Moderate Deontology)
articles.content: While categorical, moral constraints may be overridden only when the consequences reach catastrophic thresholds, beyond which strict adherence would destroy the point of morality itself. (This principle is controversial among absolutists.)

articles.title: Supererogation
articles.content: It is possible to act better than duty requires. Deontological morality recognizes actions that are praiseworthy but not obligatory, something strict consequentialism struggles to allow.

articles.title: Moral Responsibility Through One's Own Agency
articles.content: Moral assessment is rooted in an agent's own intentions and actions. One is responsible for keeping one's own moral agency free of wrongful intention or causation, even if doing so leads to suboptimal worldly outcomes.
